case_vignette: A 71-year-old female arrives to your clinic complaining of sudden vision loss. She reports that she had been in her usual state of health, until waking up this morning unable to see out of her right eye. She denies pain, but reports her right eye “feels funny.” The patient’s medical history is significant for a previous myocardial infarction, hypertension, and osteoporosis. Her current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, rovustatin, lisinopril, and alendronate. The patient’s temperature is 98°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 145/86 mmHg, pulse is 62/min, and respirations are 12/min with an oxygen saturation of 98% O2 on room air. On physical exam, the patients pupils are symmetrical in size and equally reactive to light with accommodation. Fundoscopic exam of the right eye is shown in Figure A. Left optic fundus is unremarkable.
question: Of the following, what is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I suddenly lost vision in my right eye when I woke up this morning, and my right eye feels funny, but it doesn't hurt.
Have you had any similar symptoms before?
No, I have not had any similar symptoms before.
Have you had any recent changes in your vision or any new medications?
No, there haven't been any recent changes in my vision or new medications until this vision loss occurred.
Have you had any family history of eye conditions?
I don't know about any eye conditions in my family history.
Have you had any recent headaches or dizziness?
No, I have not had any recent headaches or dizziness.
Have you had any recent changes in your sleep patterns or stress levels?
No, my sleep patterns and stress levels have been normal.
Have you had any recent changes in your diet or exercise routine?
No, my diet and exercise routine have stayed the same.
Have you had any recent travel or exposure to new environments?
No, I have not had any recent travel or exposure to new environments.
Have you had any recent infections or illnesses?
No, I have not had any recent infections or illnesses.
Have you had any recent eye exams or check-ups?
No, I haven't had any recent eye exams or check-ups.
Final Diagnosis: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) of the optic nerve.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: The patient suddenly lost vision in their right eye when they woke up in the morning, and their right eye feels unusual, although it does not hurt. They have not experienced any similar symptoms before, and there have been no recent changes in their vision or new medications. There is no known family history of eye conditions, and the patient has not experienced recent headaches or dizziness. Their sleep patterns, stress levels, diet, and exercise routine have all remained consistent. Additionally, they have not traveled to any new environments, been exposed to recent infections or illnesses, or had any recent eye exams or check-ups.
trial_0.summarized_mcq: The most likely diagnosis is Retinal vein occlusion.
